Hi all

  Nice talk :D ! Instead of dropping the species that
don't improve since a long time, giving them a luck
with higher mutations rates since reasonable. Some
issues came to my mind :
   * How to handle the fact we have several kind of
mutations ? One answer would be to randomly modify
their probability.
   * Dropping species could be also good, because it
favors exploitation of most promising species. I would
apply the adaptation of mutation rates only on the
desperate case : any global improvement since a long
time.

--- "Rafael C.P." <kurama.youko.br@...> a �crit
:

> I suggest you to read about MOGA (Mutation Only
> Genetic Algorithms) and
> AGA/LHDC/SHDC (Adaptive Genetic Algorithms). But
> it's not intended to
> increase diversity and find new solutions, it's
> intended to make the best
> possible mutations within the current population.
> Anyway, I agree that
> mutation to increase diversity is a good thing, I've
> already implemented it
> in a class some time ago (but I've used the total
> population instead of the
> rate change of fitness, which now, indeed, I think
> would be better).
> 
> On 3/20/07, shanemcdonaldryan
> <shanemcdonaldryan@...> wrote:
> >
> >   Hi my name is Shane Ryan. I am researching using
> NEAT for time series
> > prediction.
> >
> > I have been lurking in the group for the past few
> months. I've got a
> > few questions/suggestions that I'll post as three
> separate messages.
> >
> > I am wondering if anyone has tried using a
> variable mutation rate?
> > Basically if the system determines that overall
> the fitness rate
> > change has gone below a threshold value. Then
> increase the chance of
> > new nodes being added and increase the range of
> weight variations
> > until the fitness begins to improve again. Then
> lower the system wide
> > mutation rate back down again once there has been
> an improvement.
> >
> > The way I see it when the system begins to
> stagnate. Instead of
> > continuing to fine tune the system. Start making
> some much more
> > radical changes.
> >
> > Another way to do this might be too increase the
> number of species
> > based of the rate change of fitness. Essentially
> start with many
> > species then lower the overall number of species
> and increase their
> > populations when you want to fine tune the
> solutions. But if there
> > hasn't been any improvements for a significant
> amount of time start
> > increasing the variety of topologies (ie increase
> the number of
> > species) until there are some improvements.
> >
> > I searched the archives but didn't find any topics
> exactly matching
> > this. Sorry if it has been discussed ad nauseum.
> Please point me in
> > the right direction if this topic has been flogged
> to death!
> >
> > Thank you,
> >
> > Shane Ryan
> >
> >  
> >
> 
>
